entry.title: Transfer of the HUs from Outbound to Inbound
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community

I need your assistance with an issue related to the transfer of handling units from outbound delivery to inbound delivery. 

As part of an intercompany or intracompany PO/STO process, we are encountering an unexpected behavior related to Handling Units (HUs).

The context is as follows:

  • HUs are properly scanned and created during the Outbound Delivery (OD) and posted at the time of the Goods Issue (GI).
  • However, during the inbound process, these HUs are not automatically transferred into the Inbound Delivery (IBD).
  • Instead of being integrated into the pick/pack structure, they are brought in as additional product lines, which blocks the Goods Receipt (GR) process.

 Technical Environment:

  • We are not using EWM (Extended Warehouse Management) or SAP Event Management (EM).
  • The entire process is managed through custom routines.

Issues caused:

  1. Loss of visibility of the actual packaging structure used at shipment (e.g., pallets, cartons).
  2. Manual repacking is required at the receiving site, or the pallet line must be manually deleted from the IBD to allow GR to proceed.

Thanks all for your help.

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Improvements to Wave Simulation Stock Checks and Logging
entry.content:
Hello @yogesh_agarwal2 

1. A Batch in Restricted-Use. This field helps sort stock that's still under quality inspection or restricted status.

  • Use it if you want to prioritise or avoid such batches during picking.
  • Descending = checked → picks newer restricted-use batches.
  • Descending = unchecked → picks older ones.
    Only works if restricted-use stock is allowed in your stock removal strategy.

1.b SKZSI – Blocking Indicator
SKZSI flags blocked inventory.

  • It’s a sort-only field, not a filter — it won’t prevent blocked stock from being picked.
  • Descending = unchecked → sorts unblocked stock first (recommended).
  • Descending = checked → may pull blocked stock first (usually not ideal).
    Best practice: Use this with a proper stock type exclusion or storage type strategy to truly avoid blocked bins.

Let me know how it goes

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Conversion Exits and the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP)
entry.content:
Thanks @Renzo for the blog.

We just upgraded to on-prem 2023 and we're getting errors related to conversion exits we have built over the last 10 years. There are tons of them.

For example, the Bank Account number field BANKN in table KNBK has a Z conversion exit that we cannot get rid of, otherwise it will affect many tcodes which users are still using. But it's causing a lot of CDS views to fail, including I_CUSTOMER.

What is the solution in this scenario? The effort of removing these conversion exits is huge.

Thanks

entry.title: SAP Developer News August 7th, 2025
entry.content:
DESCRIPTION 

PODCAST: https://podcast.opensap.info/sap-developers/2025/08/07/%f0%9f%94%94sap-developer-news-august-7th-2025/ 

SAP Developer Challenge 

  • Fiori Element With Flexible Programming Model Developer Challenge August 2025: https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/sap-community-escape-house-for-august-fiori-element-with-flexible/ba-p/14167685 

Using Jupyter in SAP Business Application Studio and in SAP Business Data Cloud 

  • Using Jupyter in SAP Business Application Studio: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/using-jupyter-in-sap-business-application-studio-my-notes/ba-p/14167294 
  • Using conda-forge in SAP Business Application Studio: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/using-conda-forge-in-sap-business-application-studio-my-notes/ba-p/14169956  
  • Hands-on Jupyter in SAP Databricks: https://community.sap.com/t5/artificial-intelligence-and-machine-learning-blogs/hands-on-tutorial-sap-databricks/ba-p/14156999 
  • Unlocking SAP AI Foundation capabilities in SAP Databricks: A technical deep dive: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/unlocking-sap-ai-foundation-capabilities-in-sap-databricks-a-technical-deep/ba-p/14162714  
  • Recordings and Slides from webinar series 'Architecting Your SAP Business Data Cloud Journey': https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-architecture-blog-posts/recordings-and-slides-from-webinar-series-architecting-your-sap-business/ba-p/14163802   

Devtoberfest Fun Activities 

  • Devtoberfest Home Page: https://community.sap.com/t5/devtoberfest/gh-p/Devtoberfest 
  • Devtoberfest Social Media Announcement: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/sap-developers_get-ready-devtoberfest-by-sap-teched-in-activity-7354571776418324480-OPqH?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop&rcm=ACoAAAO_6sQB6ZWQRLHA4I-AqpHfE4_c2OZCYEI 
  • Devtoberfest YouTube Playlist from 2024: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL6RpkC85SLQDHz97qsNTNAE2jnUKj8X5d 
  • HIDDEN BONUS: Scramble puzzle already published that will be part of the fun activities – earn points already: https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/devtoberfest2025-fun-scramble-languages.html  
  • A good primer on cryptic crosswords: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c9ZtJMAVqqY 

 

CHAPTER TITLES  

0:00 Intro 

0:10 SAP Developer Challenge 

1:09 Demojam Promo 

1:45 Using Jupyter in SAP Business Application Studio and in SAP Business Data Cloud 

3:15 Devtoberfest Fun Activities 

 

TRANSCRIPTION

[Intro] This is the SAP Developer News for August the 7th, 2025.

[Amar] Hello, SAP developers. The August Developer Challenge now live and available in SAP developers’ community. In this month, we are diving into SAP Fiori element with flexible programming model. If you ever wanted to go beyond the standard template and tailor your app's behavior with powerful custom logic, this challenge is for you. You will get hands-on experience with flexible programming model, learn how to use extensions point, building block and controller extensions to enhance your Fiori element application. I highly recommend checking it out. The blog post with all the details about the challenge is linked below in the video description. As always, all the participants who will complete this challenge will earn the SAP Community patch. I hope you'll like it. Bye-bye.

[Tom] Hi dear, I got the demojam trophy for the winner of the Demojam at SAP TechEd Berlin this year. Thats right, demojam is back again this year and the team with the best demo will be voted on by the audience and get this fabulous price. So ,I hope everyone is looking forward to a great show this year, there are teams hard at work building on their demos as we speak. And whether you're in person Berlin or joining us online for the virtual event, you'll be able to tune in and see all the excitement of Demo Jam. So just one more reason to be looking forward to TechEd again this year.

[Witalij] Do you remember my announcement in last week's SAP Developer News about using Python in SAP Business Application Studio? Of course you do, right? This week, I've shared two new blog posts expanding on that topic. The first explores how to use Jupyter Notebooks with SAP Business Application Studio, and the second explains how to set up Conda Forge instead of the default Python virtual environment. These resources should be particularly helpful if you are working on machine learning or AI projects in bus. But what if you want to do something similar in SAP Business Data Cloud? Then you'll want to check out how Jupyter Notebooks work in SAP Databricks. Our Regional Center of Excellence team has you covered. They've published a step-by-step walkthrough for training a time-series forecasting model in SAP Business Data Cloud. What's best? You can do this in basic trial for free. Want to explore SAP Databricks more deeply? Product Management has released a two-part blog series focused specifically on that, packed with technical insights. Oh, and before I forget, recordings from the recent BDC Architecture series, including sessions on SAP Databricks, have just gone live this week. You'll find all the links in the description below.

[Daniel] Devtoberfest is right around the corner, and I hope you've seen our posts on social media. I just wanted to let you know that in addition to the dozens and dozens of learning sessions by the best presenters and the smartest developers, we'll also have a few fun treats. We'll, of course, have Pettoberfest this year with a little bit of Gen AI twist. We'll also have coding challenges, and, of course, we will bring back the SAP cryptic crossword. Now, for you newbies, cryptics are exciting to solve, also exciting to create, and I'll just give you an idea of how they work. It's like getting a crossword puzzle with clues. But unlike a regular crossword, every clue is divided into two. Half of it is a definition like any other crossword. But the other half is a play on words or something that indicates how the word is constructed. And it's your job to figure out where to break up the clue. So, for example, hybris a clue, command to round up horrific lice. Sounds a little bit weird, no? But if you look at it, you can see that you can divide it into two. Command to round up, which is a definition. Any ideas what that could be? And the second part, horrific lice. Horrific indicates it's an anagram of lice. You can rearrange the letters in lice to spell seal, a JavaScript method to round up a number. Pretty cool, no? we'll also have a scavenger hunt that will take you throughout the community throughout our youtube channel github even the help portal and you'll search for clues to the answer to the scavenger hunt and then you'll earn hundreds perhaps thousands of points towards our devtoberfest grand prize more details to come as we approach devtoberfest which starts september 29th.

entry.title: HCM Brasil - Crédito do Trabalhador (eConsignado) Importação de Parcelas de Empréstimo do Empregado
entry.content:
Olá pessoal, 

Temos novidades importantes para compartilhar sobre o Crédito do Trabalhador! Acabamos de entregar o novo relatório, "Importação de Parcelas de Empréstimo do Empregado", desenvolvido para automatizar a Inclusão de dados de empréstimos no infotipo 3453 - Desconto de Parcela em Folha, subtipo 0001 - Crédito do Trabalhador, eliminando a necessidade de inserções manuais. 

O novo relatório recebe um arquivo JSON fornecido pelo governo, contendo todas as informações das parcelas de empréstimo dos colaboradores. Com apenas alguns cliques, os dados são importados diretamente para o sistema, garantindo maior eficiência e precisão no fluxo de informações. 

Benefícios: 

  • Redução de erros e retrabalho: Importação automatizada de dados, minimizando erros de digitação. 
  • Ganho tempo e aumento de produtividade: Elimine a digitação manual e foque em atividades mais estratégicas. 
  • Maior segurança e confiabilidade: Valide os dados antes da aplicação, garantindo a integridade das informações. 

Principais funcionalidades: 

  • Opções de Filtragem: Selecione os colaboradores para a inserção de dados. 
  • Modo de Teste: valide o resultado da execução antes de salvar no sistema. 
  • Importação de Arquivos: 
    • Máquina Local: Realize a importação de arquivos JSON diretamente do seu computador. 
    • Servidor SAP: Realize a importação do arquivo JSON a partir do SAP Server. 
  • Visualização: 
    • Parcelas Inseridas com Sucesso: Exibe parcelas inseridas, organizadas por colaborador. 
    • Erros de Inserção: Relata detalhes de erros e identifica parcelas específicas. 

Instalação: 

Esse novo relatório está disponível através da SAP Note 3612659 - eConsignado - Payroll Installments Discounts Importer  

Uma vez instalada a SAP Note, o relatório estará acessível através de: 

  • Programa: Após a instalação, você poderá executar o programa RPC_PADBR_PY_INST_DISC_IMPORT que contém todas as funcionalidades necessárias. 
  • Transação: Para maior conveniência, a transação PC00_M37_INST_IMPORT permitirá que o acesso ao relatório seja direto e eficiente. 

Compartilhe sua opinião! 

Se tiver alguma dúvida, sugestão ou comentário sobre este post, sinta-se à vontade para compartilhar na seção de comentários abaixo. 

Acesse também nosso workzone exclusivo dedicado para informações sobre o Crédito do Trabalhador. 

Não se esqueça de dar um "like" neste post se você achou útil e compartilhá-lo com seus colegas. Siga a tag HCM Payroll Brazil na SAP Community para se manter atualizado sobre as últimas notícias. 

Estamos comprometidos em simplificar seus processos e apoiar suas operações de forma eficiente! 

 

Um abraço, 
Ramiro dos Santos Manoel

entry.title: Re: define user's timezone on sap lms
entry.content: @user116, "Since timezone field does not exist on the user tab" - Does this mean "user record on the Learning Adminstration area"? If so, yes, there's a way to change the user's time zone via its record on the Learning Administration area. Access the desired account > "Preferences" tab > "Time Zone ID" field. The users' time zones are generally defined when they're created in Learning. Here you can find additional details: KBAs 2288843, 2385725, and 2250834.

entry.title: The 3 Pillars of Cloud Computing
entry.content:
1. IaaS – Infrastructure as a Service

IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service) is the most “basic” layer of the cloud. Think of it as renting virtual computers, storage, and networks. You don’t need to buy physical servers—just pay for what you use, and scale resources up or down as needed.

  • Who’s in control: The user controls the operating system, storage, and applications, but doesn’t have to worry about the hardware.

  • Real-world example: Netflix uses Amazon Web Services (AWS) to host its servers. This allows them to handle massive global traffic without stressing over physical server maintenance.

SAP Solution:
SAP HANA Enterprise Cloud (HEC) is SAP’s IaaS offering. It lets companies migrate their SAP environments to a managed, high-performance, secure, and scalable cloud infrastructure. No need to worry about server maintenance, backups, or updates—SAP handles it all.

2. PaaS – Platform as a Service

PaaS (Platform as a Service) is like the “middle ground.” In addition to infrastructure, it offers tools and environments for developing, testing, and hosting applications. Developers don’t have to worry about OS updates or database installs—it’s all included!

  • Who’s in control: The user manages only apps and data. The provider handles everything else (infrastructure, OS, updates).

  • Real-world example: Spotify uses Google Cloud Platform (GCP) and its PaaS services to develop and roll out new features fast, focusing solely on code and user data.

SAP Solution:
SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) is the core of SAP’s PaaS solutions. Developers can build SAP system extensions, create intelligent apps with AI, analyze data in real time, and integrate multiple data sources. BTP provides resources for databases, advanced analytics, system integration, and app development—all in the cloud.

3. SaaS – Software as a Service

SaaS (Software as a Service) is the most familiar model for end-users. Here, you don’t install anything on your computer—just access the software via the internet, using a browser or app. Everything—infrastructure, platform, and app—is managed by the provider.

  • Who’s in control: The user simply uses the software, with no worries about installation, updates, or infrastructure.

  • Real-world example: Gmail, Google Docs, and Salesforce are classic examples. Companies like Coca-Cola use Salesforce to manage global sales securely and at scale, without having to maintain their own servers.

SAP Solutions:
This is where SAP is a global powerhouse! Some top examples:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud: A modern, intelligent cloud ERP for managing finance, operations, and more.

  • SAP SuccessFactors: A full-suite HR solution for talent management, payroll, performance, and training.

  • SAP Ariba: A complete cloud-based procurement and supplier management platform, streamlining purchasing processes.

Each of these solutions is designed for specific needs, helping companies become more digital, agile, and competitive.

How Each Pillar Delivers Data Protection

When it comes to cloud computing, security is always a top concern for companies. Sensitive data and critical operations are now managed outside your four walls. SAP knows this and invests heavily to ensure robust protection in every cloud layer: IaaS, PaaS, and SaaS. Here’s how security is managed in each:

1. IaaS (SAP HANA Enterprise Cloud)

With IaaS, SAP secures the entire infrastructure, while clients manage their apps and data.

Top security practices:

  • Certified data centers: SAP uses global data centers certified to international standards (like ISO 27001).

  • Firewalls and network segmentation: Digital barriers keep client data isolated and prevent unauthorized access.

  • Data encryption: Both in transit (on the network) and at rest (on servers).

  • Continuous monitoring: SIEM tools and 24/7 expert teams detect threats in real time.

Client’s responsibility: Manage user access to apps and maintain internal security policies.

2. PaaS (SAP Business Technology Platform)

With PaaS, SAP secures the platform (infrastructure, middleware, databases), while clients secure the applications they build.

Top security practices:

  • Identity and access management: Granular control over who can access what, including multi-factor authentication.

  • Isolated environments: Client apps run in separate spaces to prevent cross-company data leaks.

  • Compliance tools: Automated auditing, logs, and controls to meet regulations like GDPR.

  • Automatic updates: The platform is always up-to-date with the latest security patches.

Client’s responsibility: Ensure secure app development practices, like input validation and permissions management.

3. SaaS (SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SuccessFactors, Ariba)

With SaaS, SAP manages almost all aspects of security and delivers ready-to-use, protected solutions.

Top security practices:

  • End-to-end encryption: Secures all communication and stored data.

  • Role-based access controls: Users only see the info needed for their role.

  • Backup and disaster recovery: Automated routines guarantee data restoration if something goes wrong.

  • Compliance monitoring: Integrated tools to ensure global regulatory adherence (SOX, GDPR, LGPD).

Client’s responsibility: Set user access policies, review security settings, and promote internal security awareness.

Conclusion

SAP stands out for offering a complete range of cloud solutions, so companies can pick what fits best—whether it’s infrastructure, a platform, or ready-to-use software. This flexibility lets you innovate, grow, and keep your eyes on what really matters: your business results.

Understanding the differences between IaaS, PaaS, and SaaS helps companies choose the right solution for every stage or need. Cloud computing makes it possible to scale on demand, pay only for what you use, and avoid infrastructure headaches.

Want to see more examples or need tips on choosing the right model for your project? Just ask!

Sources:

SAP Brasil | Software e Soluções Inteligentes na Nuvem

SAP Business Technology Platform

Software de Gestão de Capital Humano | SAP SuccessFactors

SAP Trust Center | Security, Privacy, Cloud Status & More

entry.title: I need to list multiple datetime values from a single field in crystal reports.
entry.content:
My crystal report (2020) has a single parameter, which is based on a datetime field called MN_TIMESHEET.BEGIN_DATE.

The parameter allows multiple values to be selected, and I need to list those selections in the report header. 

I did this in a different report for a string field parameter using:

JOIN({?TRANSACTION ADMINISTRATOR}, ', ')

In my new report (with the datetime parameter) I tried and failed with variations of this:

JOIN({MN_TIMESHEET.BEGIN_DT}, "dd/MM/yyyy HH:mm:ss", ',')

Any ideas?

entry.title: Re: Integrate SAP Customer Checkout Mobile Orders with a...
entry.content:
Hello @Fedias 

Since you already have SIX (Switzerland’s Interbank Clearing) set up, I can help you check the connection and guide you through connecting an additional local bank.

Connecting to SIX

If you just need to review or test the existing setup, here are the key areas to check:

  1. Communication Arrangement
  • Open the Communication Arrangements app
  • Check for the following scenarios:
    • SAP_COM_0463 – Payment Integration
    • SAP_COM_0558 – Bank Statement Integration (if used)
  • Ensure the communication user, certificate, and endpoint are correctly configured.
  1. Payment Method Configuration
  • In Manage Your Solution > Configure Your Solution, go to:
    • Set Up Payment Methods per Company Code for Outgoing Payments
  • Make sure the payment method (e.g., ‘T’ for Switzerland) is linked to the correct output format (typically pain.001) and assigned to the SIX house bank.

Connecting a New Local Bank

To set up another bank, please follow these steps:

Step 1: Create the House Bank

  • App: Manage House Banks
  • Add your local bank using the bank key, country, SWIFT/BIC code, and internal account ID.

Step 2: Assign Bank Account

  • App: Manage Bank Accounts
  • Create or update a bank account for the relevant company code.
  • Set the currency, account type, and link it to the new house bank.

Step 3: Set Up Communication (if applicable)

  • If the local bank supports host-to-host, SFTP, or EBICS connections:
    • Set up a new Communication Arrangement using SAP_COM_0463 or SAP_COM_0558.
    • Use a similar structure to your SIX setups.

Step 4: Maintain Payment Format Settings

  • App: Maintain Payment Medium Formats
  • Assign the appropriate output format (e.g., pain.001.001.03 for payments or camt.053 for bank statements).

Optional: Run a Test Payment

  • App: Manage Automatic Payments
  • Simulate a payment using the new house bank and validate the file output.

Looking forward to your reply.

Best regards,
Chuma

GenAI Assisted Content 

  • SAP_COM_0463 – Payment Integration
  • Manage House Banks – SAP Fiori App
  • Manage Automatic Payments – SAP Help

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Best Practice Recommendation for Mixed Development Cl...
entry.content:
Hello @MeghanRosser73 

Yes, it’s still recommended to avoid mixing transports from different development clients within a single ChaRM document. Although technically feasible, this approach is unsupported and may cause version conflicts, tracking problems, and issues during retrofits or audits. Stick to a single ChaRM per development client to ensure stability and traceability.

With regards

Chuma

 

 

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3355549

3355549 - Defining multiple development clients in ChaRM

entry.title: Re: Conversion Exits and the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP)
entry.content:
Hi @Renzo ,

The conversion exit breaks the service, we get the error "Do not use conversion exit" and the service does not activate.

But my point is, we can't just remove the conversion exit, it may be used in hundreds of different places. There is no "where-used" for conversion exits, and if we remove it, it may break many tcodes/interfaces and cause legal issues for the client.

The Bank Account conversion exit is used to display ***** instead of bank account # if the user doesn't have proper authorization. We can't just remove it as you suggest in this blog. And it's impossible to know where it's used.

What are we supposed to do?

entry.title: Re: What I Wish I Knew
entry.content:
When I started, I really wished there had been a learning methodology that showed how the tool aligns with the business, using real-world examples.
It would have been so helpful to get an overview of the entire SAP ecosystem—what each link is for (SAP Community, SAP for ME, SAP Help, Business Process Navigator, etc.).

Usually, when a junior consultant starts this journey, no one really has the time to sit down and give them this kind of structured introduction.

Without this care in passing on knowledge in a clear, organized way, we end up creating consultants who are just putting out fires—without really understanding what they’re doing or why.

entry.title: Re: Accessing SAP Java NetWeaver Database Details via JMX...
entry.content:
Hello @hari0011 

You're on the right track using JMX MBeans to collect performance data from SAP NetWeaver Java. For database-related information, here are a few pointers:
1. Use the SAP-Specific MBeans via Visual Admin or JConsole

SAP NetWeaver Java provides a number of useful MBeans under:

com.sap.*

You’ll want to check:
MBean: com.sap.sql.monitoring:type=SQLDataSource

This MBean exposes high-level metadata about each configured data source, including:

JDBC URL

Active connections

Max connections

Pool usage

You can find this under:

com.sap.sql.monitoring -> SQLDataSource -> Attributes

Check the DataSourceName, URL, ConnectionCount, etc.

Note: You likely won’t see DB instance ID directly here — but you’ll get DB type, host, port from the JDBC URL.

2. Use com.sap.engine MBeans

These include internal monitoring for the Java engine and often expose runtime and resource usage data. Look under:

com.sap.engine -> system -> monitor

Though not DB-specific, some metrics link to database I/O or response times depending on the configured backend.
3. Alternative: Use NWA Diagnostic Tools

In addition to JMX, SAP recommends using NetWeaver Administrator (NWA) for full database identification and analysis:

NWA → Troubleshooting → Java System Reports

Look under Database tab

You’ll find:

Database product name/version

Host

Schema

Connected user

DB Instance ID (if supported)


Best regards,
Chuma

GenAI Assisted Content
SAP Documentation and Tooling References

SAP Help – Monitoring with JMX

JMX Monitoring in SAP Commerce-SAP Help 

SAP NetWeaver Administrator Tool (NWA)

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Convert SAP BTP Certificate Service Keys to PFX Files
entry.content:
SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) allows you to create service keys of type certificate. These certificates can be exported from BTP and imported into other systems as client certificates to securely call SAP BTP services using certificate-based authentication.

However, the BTP cockpit provides the certificate chain and the private key only in text form. While some systems may accept this format, others require the upload of a certificate file containing all these details in one piece. (In addition, since it carries the certificate's private key, this file should usually be encrypted.)

I recently set up the integration between SAP Sales/Service Cloud Version 2 and SAP Integration Suite/Cloud Integration, in which I had to convert the textual details from the service key into an encrypted PFX file.

While such tasks are often carried out with command-line tools, such as OpenSSL, where you need to remember all the correct commands, I was looking for an easy GUI-based approach. In this blog I want to explain how to create the PFX certificate with the free, multi-platform GUI tool KeyStore Explorer, which is very helpful for this task.

The process consists of three simple tasks:

  1. Create text files for the certificate chain and the key
  2. Import these files into KeyStore Explorer
  3. Save them as PFX file

 

1. Create Text Files

  1. Open the service key details in SAP BTP and switch to Form view.
  2. Certificate Chain:
    Copy the text from the certificate field into an empty text file and insert line breaks so that -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----, -----END CERTIFICATE----- and the actual certificate content (which is Base64 encoded) have separate lines. Save the file, for instance, as cert_chain.pem
    Please note that the content from the certificate field contains the whole certificate chain consisting of three certificates.
    The should look like this:

  3. Private Key:
    Copy the text from the key field into an empty text file and insert line breaks so that -----BEGIN RSA PRIVATE KEY-----, -----END RSA PRIVATE KEY----- and the actual key content (which is Base64 encoded) have separate lines. Save the file, for instance, as key.pem

That's it for the preparation step.

 

2. Import Text Files

  1. Open KeyStore Explorer and create a new keystore with the type PKCS#12.

  2. Select the Import Key Pair button in the toolbar and choose OpenSSL as import type. 

  3. In the import dialog, uncheck the Encrypted Private Key checkbox and provide the previously created files for the private key and the certificate file.

  4. You will be prompted for an alias for the keystore. You can simply accept the suggested one. 

  5. Another dialog will appear that asks you to enter a New Key Pair Entry Password.
    Enter a strong password.
    My suggestion: Generate a password with a password manager to store it securely, and Copy&Paste it.
    We'll need this password again when saving the PFX file and later when importing it into the target system/tool.

 

With that, we have all the necessary details in the keystore and can view all the details of the imported files:

 

 

3. Save PFX File

  1. With the full certificate chain and the private key imported into the key store, we can now save the keystore as PFX file.
    In this step, we have to enter a password again to protect the file (since it contains the secret private key).
    Use the same password as during the import. This password will also be needed when uploading the PFX file into a system/tool of your preference.
  2. In the last step, enter a filename for the PFX file, for instance client_cert_enc.pfx
     

That's it! Now you can import the PFX file into the system/tool where you need it. For instance into the Communication System of an SAP Sales/Service Cloud Version 2 system:

I hope this blog is helpful!

entry.title: Re: Functionality to attach pdf to freight order to see t...
entry.content:
Hello @VaibhavVS33 

To attach a PDF document (like a checklist) to a Freight Order (TOR) in SAP Transportation Management (TM) using BOPF, and see it reflected in the BOPF object browser (BOBT), follow this approach:
 Key Components You Need to Use

BO: /SCMTMS/TOR

Nodes:

ATTACHMENTFOLDER

DOCUMENT

FILECONTENT

Implementation Steps in ABAP

Here’s a simplified outline using ABAP and the BOPF API:
1. Convert Base64 PDF string to XSTRING

DATA: lv_pdf_xstring TYPE xstring.

CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_BASE64_DECODE_STR'
EXPORTING
input = lv_base64_string
IMPORTING
output = lv_pdf_xstring.

2. Create Attachment via BOPF Modify

DATA: lt_modifications TYPE /bobf/t_frw_modification,
ls_mod TYPE /bobf/s_frw_modification,
lv_key_tor TYPE /bobf/conf_key, "TOR key
lv_key_attach TYPE /bobf/conf_key,
lv_key_doc TYPE /bobf/conf_key,
lv_key_content TYPE /bobf/conf_key.

" Get keys
lv_key_attach = cl_bopf_uuid=>create_uuid( ).
lv_key_doc = cl_bopf_uuid=>create_uuid( ).
lv_key_content = cl_bopf_uuid=>create_uuid( ).

" Attachment folder
ls_mod-key = lv_key_attach.
ls_mod-node = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_node-attachmentfolder.
ls_mod-change_mode = /bobf/if_frw_c=>sc_modify-create.
ls_mod-parent_key = lv_key_tor.
ls_mod-association = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_association-tor-attachmentfolder.
APPEND ls_mod TO lt_modifications.

" Document
CLEAR ls_mod.
ls_mod-key = lv_key_doc.
ls_mod-node = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_node-document.
ls_mod-change_mode = /bobf/if_frw_c=>sc_modify-create.
ls_mod-parent_key = lv_key_attach.
ls_mod-association = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_association-attachmentfolder-document.
ls_mod-data = VALUE #( mime_type = 'application/pdf'
filename = 'Checklist.pdf' ).
APPEND ls_mod TO lt_modifications.

" File content
CLEAR ls_mod.
ls_mod-key = lv_key_content.
ls_mod-node = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_node-filecontent.
ls_mod-change_mode = /bobf/if_frw_c=>sc_modify-create.
ls_mod-parent_key = lv_key_doc.
ls_mod-association = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_association-document-filecontent.
ls_mod-data = VALUE #( file_content = lv_pdf_xstring ).
APPEND ls_mod TO lt_modifications.

3. Execute Modify Call

DATA(lo_srv_mgr) = /bobf/cl_tra_serv_mgr_factory=>get_service_manager( iv_bo_key = /scmtms/if_tor_c=>sc_bo_key ).

CALL METHOD lo_srv_mgr->modify
EXPORTING
it_modification = lt_modifications
IMPORTING
eo_message = DATA(lo_msg)
eo_change = DATA(lo_change).

IF lo_msg->check( ) IS NOT INITIAL.
"Handle error
ENDIF.

Important Prerequisites

Attachment Schema Must Be Defined:

Use app or config /SCMTMS/CUST_ATT_SCH (Define Attachment Schema for TOR).

Ensure the attachment schema is assigned in TM customizing.

Storage Category:

Use ArchiveLink or Generic Object Services (GOS) backend storage settings.

Check Authorization:

Make sure your user has permission to update attachments for TOR.

BOBF Dump (/BOBF/CX_FRW_FATAL):

Typically caused by:

Missing parent-child associations

Invalid keys

Missing configuration like attachment schema


TL;DR – Quick Summary
Step Task
1 Decode PDF Base64 to XSTRING
2 Use BOPF modify method for /SCMTMS/TOR
3 Create entries for ATTACHMENTFOLDER, DOCUMENT, FILECONTENT
4 Ensure correct configuration: attachment schema, storage, associations

With regards
Chuma


GenAI Assisted Content
Reference Links

SAP Note 2361702 – Working with the BOPF AP

2244802 - Communication Error 14 due to backend sessions in ECC are not terminated - SAP Work Manager

SAP Help Portal – SAP Transportation Management Attachments

SAP BOPF Developer Guide

entry.title: Re: ERROR: J1B_NFE048 - Creating a NFE (Nota Fiscal)
entry.content:
Hello @Carolina15 

You encounter this error because SAP needs a unique number range for each CNPJ. To fix it, create a new number range (not 01) via SNRO for object J_1BNFDOCN, then assign this new range to your business place and NF type using J1BTNR.

Let me know if it works

entry.title: Re: Not able to upload XLSX file from Front end system (f...
entry.content:
If Office Integration is required, then SAPGUI for Windows needs to be used.

SAPGUI for HTML (WEBGUI) does not support Office Integration.

 

More information can be found in these KBAs:

0003145902 - "SOFFICEINTEGRATION006 error message raised while using the standard transaction or custom code through Fiori"


0002717865 - "WEBGUI: Office Integration is not supported"

entry.title: Re: Email Notification in BPA
entry.content:
@FabioDagostin1
I set up notifications for forms and approvals.
https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/enable-notifications?locale=en-US
I also had trouble sending notification emails, but I was able to resolve the issue by following the instructions at the following URL to set up notifications without fail.
I did not create a destination called “SAP_NOTIFICATION_CENTER.”
The issue I encountered was with the SMTP Mail Destination.
https://help.sap.com/docs/build-work-zone-standard-edition/sap-build-work-zone-standard-edition/configuring-smtp-mail-destination?locale=en-US
I specified Gmail for SMTP, but I set the user and password for Basic authentication in the SMTP Mail Destination.
However, what I should have set here was the user and App Password.
https://support.google.com/mail/thread/205453566/how-to-generate-an-app-password?hl=en

entry.title: How to prevent developer to import transports through Charm
entry.content:
Hi Team, 

How to prevent developer to import transports through Charm. we dont have a consistency check with SAME_USER on status imported into production.

is there any alternative to make this as hard stop, if the same user (who created NC and who is a developer) is importing into production using Normal change or Urgent change docs

Thanks,

Fakruddeen Shaik


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to prevent developer to import transports through...
entry.content:
Hi Fakruddeen,

Regarding your concern, I think you may try below:

For either normal change or urgent change, before triggering the import, you need to pass to test, only test is passed, you could trigger the import. If you don't want developer to trigger the import, you could make the developer is different as tester, in standard we have consistency check SMAE_USER to check if developer is the same as tester. but it is just a warning and won't block the status change, for your case, you may change the message type to Cancel, that's means if the developer and tester are the same, then you don't allow the status change, then the developer cannot trigger the import. But this way only blocks the import from change document level, if developer go to task list->schedule the import, he may also could trigger the import. and for task list, you may use authorization object SM_CM_FUNC to restrict the developer actions on cycle task list.

Best regards

entry.title: Re: small batch trial production
entry.content:
1. Regarding to the Phantom item, you may consider to use the phantom indicator in the BOM master instead of maintaining it in material master. By using this indicator in BOM master, you can take this material as phantom item or not in different BOM/Production version under different business situation. 

2. For the procurement type,  you may consider to use type X for this kind of materials.

entry.title: B1 HANA Client can't connect to NAT IP instead searching for HANA server IP
entry.content:
Hi,

We are using B1 HANA V10 FP2502 HF1, the network setting at my customer office is using NAT, meaning all the client workstation connect to server via NAT, there is mapping between NAT IP and SAP HANA server hostname in their DNS. 

However, at B1 HANA client login, we have detected that it is trying to connect to HANAServer IP instead of the NAT IP or HANA Server hostname and as a result, it has connection to database is lost error.

In the HANA Studio installed at client workstation, it is able to connect to HANA database, only the B1 HANA client can't connect.

We have also tried to add in the NAT IP, HANA Server IP and HANA Server Host Name inside Hosts file, it doesn't help.

Anyone have similar experience? We have found below guide but not sure should we try as previously we have tried something else and it cause connection issue, ended up spending few days to recover it.

Use of Virtual/Secondary host name with SAP HANA | sapbasispro

Appreciate if any expert is able to help, thanks a lot in advance for any advice.

Regards,

MH

entry.title: Re: Triggering Process in Shared Environments from SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
FYI

I solved this by creating a bpa instance for a specific environment.
By specifying the following in Configure instance parameters when creating the instance, these specifications are not required when calling the API.

{
  “environmentId” : “<Environment ID>”,
  “apiKey” : “<Api Key>”
}

entry.title: Re: Display String function not working in CR 2025
entry.content:
here's a few more tests....

What version of SQL Server are you using?

Go here and see if your version is supported:

https://www.sap.com/documents/2025/03/f2de681a-fa7e-0010-bca6-c68f7e60039b.html

Download the Excel file to get a list... under Data sources

Please consult the xlsx file CR2025 Data Access
Notes
• Crystal Reports is offered as a 64-bit native binary. It requires 64-bit data source middleware connectivity on all operating systems.
• Crystal Reports uses the 64-bit ODBC registry on all versions of Windows. To administer 64-bit ODBC DSNs on 64-bit versions of Windows, run the 64-bit ODBC
Administrator, located here: %windir%\System32\odbcad32.exe
 

How are you connecting, OLE DB or ODBC? I've seen this happen before, MS Client has issues with specific data type.

Try using OLE DB or ODBC, which ever you are not using.

See if using CR's Database logging component catches anything:

1603398 - How to trace data source connections in Crystal Reports using crlogger? [Video]

Try a different field, either a number or another string type field.

If using ODBC see if adding logging catches anything. Or enable logging on SQL Server to see what CR is sending it.

If you show SQL in CR what does it show before and after?

entry.title: How to define business place for Taiwan?
entry.content:
When defining the business place for Taiwan in the activity configuration "Define Business Place" (ID:102847), the error "The company code you entered is not located in any of the countries/regions where the business place functions are supported" occurred.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to define business place for Taiwan?
entry.content:
Kindly use another configuration activity "Define Business Places for Taiwan" (ID:106596).

  • If you assign multiple business places to one company code, business place of the head office will be used. You can set the business place for your head office in the Maintain Additional Parameters configuration activity.

Then you can maintain the business place assignment in the following configuration activities.

  • Assign Business Places to Sales Offices configuration activity

    For documents from Sales and Distribution (SD), business place value is maintained at sales office level.

  • Assign Business Places to Plants configuration activity

    For documents from Materials Management (MM), business place value is maintained at plant level.

entry.title: Re: Is there any way to trigger the data update in tables...
entry.content:
Hi, 

We don't recommend you to continue using the Logistical Information System table to be as the source data of any customized report. Since it is part of the SAP S/4HANA compatibility scope, which comes with limited usage rights.  Please check below SAP note for more detail:  2268063 - S4TWL - Logistic Information System in PP - SAP for Me

entry.title: The sales order has already been approved, but the subsequent billing process cannot be carried out.
entry.content:
Dear experts,

 

SO 133 has been approved ; however, subsequent billing cannot be carried out. We then attempted to trigger the approval process again in the sales order, but the approver was unable to see this sales order in their inbox. Could you advise what is causing this issue?

Furthermore, in the 【Flexible Workflow Administration】, the workflow status for this sales order is displayed as 'Error'.

 

Thanks,

Noni

entry.title: Re: Receipt of PT in another plant and its warehouse
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Public Cloud you don’t use SPRO → MM02 to switch on Special Procurement or Procurement Plant fields. Instead, all “hidden” material-master fields are exposed (or kept hidden) via your Business Configuration in the Configure Your Solution app (CBC). Until you make those fields visible there, they simply won’t appear on the MRP 2 view of the product.

Follow the below steps
Open the Configure Your Solution Fiori tile. This is your Cloud Edition equivalent of SPRO. Pick your Implementation Project. Search for “Define Material Master Field Selection”. Under the Master Data or Product to Plan group, you’ll see entries for each material-master view (Basic, Sales, Purchasing, MRP1, MRP2, etc.). Expand the MRP2 View field-selection node. Scroll down to the fields

  • Special Procurement Key
  • Procurement Plant
  • Production Storage Location - Mark each as Visible (Optional) or even Required, then Save.

Refresh your Material-Master app, Go back to Manage Product Master Data (or whatever product-master Fiori tile you use). Open the material → Change mode → switch to the MRP 2 view. You’ll now see the Special Procurement and Procurement Plant dropdowns. Maintain Your MTO Logic. Set Special Procurement Key = 50 (In-House Production). Enter Procurement Plant = 55MY. Optionally fill Production Storage Location = 55LS so your warehouse defaults correctly and save.

Run MRP for Plant 5510. System will now generate a planned order in 55MY (the procurement plant). You convert that planned order in 55MY to a production order (CO40 or your Fiori equivalent), and everything—components, confirmations, GR—stays in the manufacturing plant/warehouse you intended.

In nutshell, why this solves your issue is because,

  • The order header’s plant is locked because you initially created the MTO order at 5510.
  • By using special‐procurement key 50 + procurement plant 55MY, you let the system plan and execute production in 55MY without ever changing the order header.
  • The production‐order you convert in 55MY will then default your EWM warehouse assignment (55SL) correctly, and all goods‐issues/receipts will post against the proper plant/storage‐location/warehouse.

entry.title: Re: The sales order has already been approved, but the su...
entry.content:
Your sales‐order billing is still blocked because the flexible‐workflow that was supposed to “release” the order never completed successfully. In your Flexible Workflow Administration you see the status “Error” because the approval step ran into a runtime problem. Since the workflow didn’t finish, no work item ever landed in the approver’s inbox—and the system never removed the billing block from the order.

Why no one sees the Order in My Inbox is because, the approval step raised an error before it could resolve its agent. When agent determination fails, the work item isn’t assigned to anyone and gets flagged as an error. No valid work item → nothing shows up in the approver’s My Inbox.

Why the Billing still Blocked is because, the order header is still in “In Approval” status. As long as Approval Status ≠ Approved, billing functions (VF01/VF04 or Fiori billing apps) are locked. The incomplete workflow never toggled the standard “Release for Billing” flag.

Below are some Root‐Cause Checklist

Error Details In Flexible Workflow Administration, click the Error link for your order. Drill into the step history to see the exact failure (agent determination, authorization, missing OData service, etc.).

Agent Determination Open the Work Items without Agents app. If your order appears here, it means the system couldn’t resolve an approver. Ensure your task definitions are classified as General Task (not “Transfer Authorized”). Confirm your approver user/role is correctly assigned in Manage Teams and Responsibilities.

Activate & Validate the Scenario In Manage Workflows for Sales, verify that your workflow scenario for this document type is active and that all preconditions (value thresholds, item categories, sales org, etc.) match this order.

Runtime Environment & Jobs Run transaction SWU3 (Edit Runtime Environment) to make sure the generic workflow setup is green. Verify that the background jobs (e.g. SAP_WFRT or SAP_WIRKFLOW_SYSTEM) are scheduled and running without errors.

Authorization & OData Services Use SU53 after reproducing the error to catch missing authorizations for the workflow runtime user. Check /IWFND/ERROR_LOG for any missing or inactive OData service calls (the Fiori button “Trigger Approval” uses an OData action).

Follow the below steps to fix this and get billing moving again

  • In Flexible Workflow Administration, select the errored instance and choose Resume (after you’ve corrected the root cause).
  • Confirm that a new work item lands in My Inbox.
  • Once the approver approves, the order’s Approval Status flips to “Approved” and the billing block is removed.
  • Run your billing transaction (VF01/VF04 or the corresponding Fiori app) to create the invoice.

entry.title: Re: Bank Guarantee as noted item in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Public Cloud the classic Special G/L indicators (E = Guarantee, I = Guarantee Received) are not delivered for standard A/R or A/P processing—only down-payments (A/K) are in scope. That means you won’t find a Fiori tile “Post Bank Guarantee” or an option in “Post Incoming Payments” to pick a guarantee‐type noted item.

Public Cloud scope for Special G/L in A/R–A/P covers only down‐payments (indicators A and K). Guarantees (E or I) traditionally require on-premise SPRO customizing (OBXT, OBXS) which you cannot access in the Cloud Edition. There is no hidden Fiori app or CBC toggle to “turn on” guarantee indicators for customer/vendor line‐item management.


Some options and workarounds are:

Use a Down-Payment as Proxy
Post a down-payment request (Special G/L A or K) in the “Post Incoming Payments” (A/R) or “Post Outgoing Payments” (A/P) Fiori app. Report on open down-payments by customer or vendor to track collateral. When the guarantee is called, clear this down payment via the standard clearing process.

Leverage Treasury & Risk Management (TRM)
If your scope includes TRM (scope item FIN-TRM), you can use the Manage Bank Guarantee Fiori app: Create a Guarantee Instrument → Attach to Business Partner → Monitor expiry. This becomes a true financial instrument—separate from your subledger line items.

Custom Business Object (CBO) Extension
Extend your Cloud solution by creating a CBO “Bank Guarantee” with the fields you need. Build a simple Fiori UI to capture guarantee details and link it via Business Partner; schedule a monthly report for expiries.

If you’re not on TRM today, the fastest path is to post an A-type down-payment noted item via Post Incoming Payments (for customer collateral) or Post Outgoing Payments (for vendor collateral). Then:

  • in the Fiori app, select Special G/L Indicator = A (Customer Down-Payment) or K (Vendor Down‐Payment).
  • Enter your Bank GL Account (i.e. the “cash collateral” account) as the G/L.
  • Simulate → Post.

Use a custom report or CDS view to surface open down‐payments “held as bank guarantees,” and clear them when the guarantee expires or is called.

entry.title: How to perform SSO authentication to Concur in the background from BTP LaunchPad
entry.content:
Background

We have configured SSO authentication from BTP LaunchPad to SAP Concur using Azure AD via IAS.
Currently, the LaunchPad tile is configured to open the following URL directly: https://www.concursolutions.com/.
After the user clicks the tile, the Concur login page appears, and SSO is successfully performed when the user clicks the "Sign in with SSO" button.

However, our requirement is as follows:
When a user launches Concur from the BTP LaunchPad, we want the SSO process to run automatically in the background, so that the user is taken directly to the post-login screen without needing to click anything.

Current Setup

  • BTP LaunchPad → IAS → Azure AD for SSO authentication

  • SSO to Concur works correctly when initiated manually from the login page

  • LaunchPad tile URL is https://www.concursolutions.com/

Question

  • Is there a way to trigger the SSO authentication automatically when navigating to Concur from BTP LaunchPad?

  • Alternatively, is there a URL pattern or configuration that can initiate the SSO flow without requiring user interaction?

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public Cloud 2508 Migration Cockpit: Material...
entry.content:
When you include the Warehouse Management Extension sheet in the standard Product migration template, the cockpit now performs an existence check against EWM‐related master data and customizing. In the 2508 release, SAP tightened this validation so that if your target system isn’t yet set up for EWM (no active EWM storage locations, no EWM product extension records), the simulation throws:

“The material <matnr> does not exist or is not activated”.

In earlier releases the cockpit silently skipped the EWM sheet; in 2508 it fails fast.

Why the other files worked Pre-2508 is because, previous releases did not validate EWM extension data at simulation. Your uploads with EWM sheets passed because the cockpit ignored the empty or incomplete EWM fields. After 2508, the cockpit enforces that if you supply an EWM‐extension row, the product must already be activated for that warehouse storage location.

Recommended approach

  • Remove EWM Extension from Product Upload. Delete or clear the Warehouse Management Extension sheet in your Excel. Run the Product migration simulation – it will succeed as before. Later, load your EWM data using the dedicated EWM migration objects.
  • Use Dedicated EWM Migration Objects. SAP provides specific migration objects for EWM master data (e.g., Warehouse Product, Storage Bins, Fixed Bins) under the “SAP EWM to Decentralized EWM” scenario. Migrate Product → then Warehouse Product via object /SCWM/MATWMGR or similar. This two-step approach keeps your core Product load separate from EWM setup.
  • Pre-Provision EWM Customizing (if you must keep EWM rows). Configure your target EWM warehouse, storage locations, and link material to EWM in Configure Your Solution before migration. Ensure the material is “activated” for EWM (via Manage Product Master Data → EWM tag). Re-run simulation; the cockpit will find the expected EWM entries and allow the Product load.

entry.title: Best practices for splitting software collections with dependency safety
entry.content:
In our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition environment, we currently group non-role-related changes (e.g., UI extensions, logic, configurations) into a single software collection due to dependency concerns.

However, since software collections cannot be released independently (no "overtaking"), we're facing a challenge where delays in a few objects block the release of all others in the same collection.

Given this, we’re looking for any practical best practices or decision rules for how to split software collections that:

  • Avoid import errors caused by object dependencies, and

  • Allow more flexible, decoupled release cycles

If anyone has defined objective rules, patterns, or decision flows for structuring collections under these constraints, I would greatly appreciate your input.
